description: Probably from Portuguese lingüista (“linguist”) reinterpreted as linguist +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: (archaic, historical) An interpreter, especially one interpreting between European and non-European languages in colonial contexts. [17th–19th c.]
examples: […]  the Portuguese very privatly gives information  […]  that it [the murder] was done by one of my people and by my order[;] this young man whom they accused was my linguister  […]

entries.meaning: (archaic, historical, by extension) In West and Central Africa, a bi- or multilingual agent or broker facilitating trade between Europeans and non-Europeans. [18th–19th c.]
examples: One day a linguister, a native commission agent, arrived in a trading canoe, and stated that  […]  a prince some way up the river  […]  had [said]  […]  that if I sent him five longs and five gallons of rum he would  […]  let my trade pass.
